title: Feminist protesters storm the red carpet at Suffragette premiere
text:
Feminist protesters storm the red carpet at Suffragette premiere Feminist protesters storm the red carpet at Suffragette premiere 
Press Association 2014 / / National Entertainment News Share 
Feminist protesters hit the red carpet tonight alongside stars of the film Suffragette at the opening night of the BFI London Film Festival. Sisters Uncut lying on the red carpet at the premiere (Ian West/PA) 
Scenes from real life mirrored those in the drama, starring Carey Mulligan, Meryl Streep and Anne-Marie Duff, as groups of women from Sisters Uncut, wearing tops with posters stuck on saying “Two women killed every week” and “Dead women can’t vote”, jumped the barriers and laid on the carpet while actresses Helena Bonham Carter, Anne-Marie Duff and Romola Garai carried out interviews. Carey Mulligan and Romola Garai (Ian West/PA) 
“We are suffragettes,” they shouted. “Domestic violence cuts kill.” 
They were referring to cuts to domestic abuse services. Other protesters held banners with the words “50/50 Parliament”, calling for equality in the British government. Anne-Marie Duff with her husband James McAvoy (Ian West/PA) 
Romola said: “I haven’t spoken to them or seen their demands but I’m happy to see the suffrage movement is alive and happening.” 
Helena also applauded the protesters saying: “I think it’s marvellous. That is exactly what the suffragettes were about… Hopefully the film will inspire anybody who feels an injustice has been done, to be bold enough to protest.” Promoted stories Protesters kicking up a storm (Joel Ryan/AP) 
Written by The Iron Lady’s Abi Morgan and directed by Sarah Gavron, Suffragette tells the story of the British women’s suffrage movement of the late 19th and early 20th century as Emmeline Pankhurst led a call for female rights to be recognised. 
New mother Carey, who plays aspiring suffragette Maud Watts, said becoming a parent has made the film “more poignant”. Meryl Streep (Joel Ryan/AP) 
She said: “Hopefully this film will inspire everyone in the way they view the world. We are an unbalanced society – women and men – and films like this inspire conversations about how we can correct that imbalance.” 
Carey, who is married to musician Marcus Mumford, said women still have a long way to go before they are on an equal footing to men. Helena Bonham Carter (Ian West/PA) 
“It’s slow and steady. We are optimistic that things need to change and brilliant actresses like Jennifer Lawrence are making enormous amounts of money in the box office and Hollywood is starting to realise there might be something in it.” 
Anne-Marie Duff, who has a young son with husband James McAvoy, has also been educating her child about gender equality. 
She explained: “We are all the same. It doesn’t matter what bits of flesh we have – we are all equal. And if we have the same skills we should be paid equally for them.” Romola, Helena, Anne-Marie and Carey look stunning in their red-carpet ensembles (Ian West/PA) 
Earlier at the film’s press conference, Meryl – who portrays activist Pankhurst – hit out at the male-dominated filmmaking industry, saying the inequality made her “infuriated.” Share article 
Suffragette opened the BFI London Film Festival, which runs until October 18. Promoted Stories
